awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mathematical, Numerical, and Experimental Investigation of Flow Sensing by the Primary Cilium
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary team of three investigators will integrate mathematical modeling, numerical simulations, and experiments to investigate key fundamental issues surrounding the mechanosensory roles of primary cilia. Primary cilia are solitary (one per cell), immotile, antenna-like microtubule-based organelles extending from the surface of nearly every mammalian cell. Mechanical stimuli (such as blood flow) cause deflection of the primary cilium, initiating downstream signaling cascades to the rest of the cell. Defects in primary cilia have been associated with atherosclerosis, osteoporosis, and cancer. Yet the biochemical signaling pathways from primary cilia bending to cellular responses remain a complex and unsolved problem that will be addressed by the three PIs. Results from the proposed research will further our understanding of subcellular mechanosensing of primary cilia, and will lay the foundation for designing therapeutic strategies to treat various human diseases due to defected primary cilia. The PIs will engage both undergraduate and graduate students to conduct interdisciplinary research, and results from the proposed research can provide new approaches in mathematical biology, biophysics, biomedical engineering and medicine. The methods and techniques to be developed in this project will go beyond the context of primary cilia and extend to other problems featuring mechanically induced cellular functions, for example, in the regulation of vascular tone. 

Long speculated to trigger intracellular calcium release as a second messenger for subsequent cellular biochemical signaling and responses (such as change in patterns of cytoskeleton or altered ion and solvent transport), recent experiments using genetically-coded calcium indicators refuted the calcium-responsiveness of primary cilia for a range of cells. Thus it is imperative to establish fundamental understanding of the role of primary cilia in subcellular mechanosensing. One main challenge to identify the pathway(s) from cilium bending to subsequent bio-chemical signaling is to isolate primary cilium contribution from the rest of the cell responding directly to the same mechanical stimuli. By using an optical trap, PI Resnick is able to bend a single primary cilium without exerting force on the rest of the cell, thus providing a great opportunity for insight to the missing pathways. Combining this experimental technique with mathematical modeling (PI Young) and numerical simulations (PI Peng), the team aims to (1) characterize the mechanical properties of the primary cilium, (2) qualify the coupling between cilium and cytoskeleton, and (3) identify the time scales and characteristics of signaling activation to quantify ciliary-mediated flow sensing. Results from these three aims will advance the mathematical modeling of the primary cilium and how it couples to the intracellular signaling pathways. 

This award is co-funded with the Cellular Dynamics and Function program in Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, and the Life Science Venture Fund in DMS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project offer significant advancements in understanding the mechanics and mechanosensing capabilities of primary cilia, with notable contributions to intellectual merit and broader impacts.

 

Intellectual Merit

Validation and Innovation in Modeling. The project successfully validated computational models against analytical solutions, ensuring reliability. A key achievement was the development of a microstructure-based primary cilium model (Fig. 1), explicitly distinguishing between microtubules and the cilium membrane. This approach enabled the accurate prediction of stress conditions in the membrane, which were previously conflated with microtubule stresses in traditional models. The refined modeling reveals how deformation modes and stress distributions depend on the cilium's length and structure, providing deeper insights into mechanosensing mechanisms.

Length-Dependent Mechanical Properties. The findings highlight the role of cilium length in its mechanical behavior and mechanosensing ability. Short cilia exhibit deformation patterns significantly different from those predicted by isotropic models, while this difference reduces for longer cilia. This work underscores the importance of length-dependent persistence lengths of microtubules in shaping the mechanics of primary cilia.

Integration of Imaging and Simulation. Incorporating electron microscopy data, the models demonstrated enhanced accuracy in capturing the interactions between microtubules and the cilium membrane (Fig. 2). Simulated optical tweezer experiments provided insights into the distinct mechanical roles of microtubules and membranes during bending, challenging traditional mechanosensing paradigms based on membrane stretching.

Insights into Mechanosensing. The stress distribution findings challenge the classical Euler beam theory, suggesting that local membrane curvature changes, rather than stretching, drive mechanosensitive protein activation (Fig. 3). A 3D calcium diffusion model was developed to explore signaling delays, potentially caused by structural viscoelastic responses and diffusion barriers. These findings reconcile conflicting observations in the field and contribute to a refined understanding of mechanosensing pathways.

Dissemination and Publications. The project outcomes were disseminated through publications, including a paper in Cytoskeleton and a collaborative review in Mathematical Biosciences and Engineering. These works provide a comprehensive framework for integrating experimental, numerical, and mathematical approaches in mechanobiology.

 

Broader Impacts

Advancing Multidisciplinary Research. The anisotropic shell models for microtubules developed through this project extend beyond cilium mechanics to impact other biophysical fields, such as cell division, intracellular transport, and motility. This approach also fosters collaboration among experts in biomechanics, bioinformatics, and mechanobiology.

Contribution to Education. The project served as an educational tool across undergraduate and graduate courses. In BME325 Biotransport, undergraduate students learned about multiscale transport phenomena in the kidney, including blood filtration and ciliary calcium dynamics. They applied MATLAB to model calcium diffusion, gaining practical computational skills. Graduate students in BME538 Numerical Analysis and Multiscale Modeling developed MATLAB finite element codes for axisymmetric stress analysis in anisotropic shells. These activities enriched the curriculum and enhanced students' understanding of computational modeling and biomechanics.

Training of Future Scientists. The project trained graduate students in cutting-edge computational techniques, including finite element simulations and fluid-structure interaction modeling using COMSOL. These trainees gained expertise in multiphysics simulations and statistical analyses, equipping them for careers in multidisciplinary research fields.

Impact on Ciliopathies and Medical Interventions. The project's findings are highly relevant to understanding ciliopathies, including Bardet-Biedl syndrome, polycystic kidney and liver disease, and Alstrom syndrome. By elucidating how cilium length and deformation influence mechanical properties and mechanosensing, the models provide a basis for developing targeted medical therapies.

 

Conclusion

This project significantly advances the field of cilium mechanics and mechanosensing by integrating innovative modeling, experimental validation, and interdisciplinary collaboration. The findings not only challenge existing paradigms but also open avenues for new research in biophysics, mechanobiology, and medical applications. Through its contributions to education and training, the project also ensures the development of the next generation of scientists equipped to tackle complex problems at the intersection of biology and engineering.
